title: How to Choose a Can of Fake Snow

steps.headline: Look for fake snow at your local craft supply store.
steps.description: Most craft stores have entire sections devoted to Christmas-themed decorations and materials around the holidays. If your favorite store is one of them, start your search there to save yourself time. Otherwise, you’ll usually find flocking with other spray-on paints and finishing products. You can also order fake snow online if you’re having trouble finding it in-store. Online vendors typically offer larger selections, so you’ll be able to browse different products to find exactly what you want at a price that fits your budget.

steps.headline: Scan the ingredients list for harmful chemicals.
steps.description: Flocking sprays are aerosolized, and may use any number of organic compounds or chemicals to impart color, including acrylates, acetates, and chlorides. This means that allergies, skin, eye, and lung irritation, or other adverse reactions could be a concern. Different products are made using different ingredients. Before you bring a particular brand home, it's important to confirm that there’s nothing in it that could pose a threat to your health, or that of your loved ones.Tip: If you or someone in your family has sensitive airways or often experience difficulty breathing, it may be best to use a natural type of flocking, such as soap shavings or desiccated coconut. Alternatively, you can try making your own snow at home using ingredients that you know are safe.

steps.headline: Make sure the amount listed is enough to complete all of your planned projects.
steps.description: Estimate how many cans you’ll need to finish decorating, then grab one more, just in case. A little bit of flocking goes a long way. Still, it’s easy to run through a canister of fake snow quicker than you might expect, especially if you intend to spray more than one piece. A single can should be enough to add a light-to-moderate coat to a miniature tree, or multiple wreaths or other pieces. Packaging sizes can vary between products and brands. Some of the most common sizes you'll find are 9 oz. (255 g), 10 oz. (283 g), 13 oz. (368 g), and 18 oz. (510 g). Depending on the use you have in mind for your fake snow, you might be able to get away with purchasing one or two large cans as opposed to several smaller cans.

steps.headline: Check the price tag to make sure you're getting a good deal.
steps.description: A standard 9-ounce (255 g)  can of flocking spray will run you about $5 on average. However, other brands may sometimes offer the same basic product for around $3 or less. Any of these products will produce the desired effect, so take a bargain when you can and save your hard-earned pennies for buying presents. Don't forget to take product size into consideration. Overall, a 13 oz. (368 g) can at $6.25 is a better deal than a 9 oz. (255 g) can at $5.50. Keep an eye out for special sales for an opportunity to save even more.

steps.headline: Look for glitter sprays if you want to give your items a realistic frosty look.
steps.description: Glitter sprays are just like ordinary flocking sprays, only with tiny pieces of glitter suspended in the colored fluid, which gives the dried snow an icy sparkle. When applied to various surfaces, they can add an element of true-to-life wintry beauty. Keep in mind that sprays containing glitter will be even tougher to control and clean that normal sprays. If you decide to go this route, you'll want to take extra precautions to protect your work area in order to ensure that you don’t get glitter anywhere you don’t want it.

steps.headline: Choose an open, well-ventilated space to serve as your work area.
steps.description: If possible, move the item you want to spray to a part of your home with at least one door or window to better allow the aerosolized chemicals to disperse. If for some reason that’s not an option, leave your air conditioner running while you work to increase the airflow in the room. Open doors or windows on opposite sides of the room to create cross-ventilation and help fumes escape faster. Switching on the ceiling fan or setting out a portable box fan can also help clear the air in your work area.

steps.headline: Wear hand and eye protection to work cleanly and safely.
steps.description: Before you get started, pull on some rubber gloves and a pair of safety glasses or goggles. These simple measures will keep the potentially-irritating chemicals and compounds in the spray from coming into contact with your skin and eyes. Be sure to strap on a facemask as well if you have asthma or a similar airway-affecting illness.

steps.headline: Place a sheet of plastic, cardboard, or newspaper under your item.
steps.description: Things have the potential to get a little messy when you’re working with fake snow. An extra layer of material will serve as a protective buffer and help you avoid dusting your floor, table, or countertops by accident. If you don’t have any old boxes or newspapers lying around, snip the sides of a garbage bag, unfold it, and stretch it out over your work station. It may also be a good idea to change into an old set of clothes that you don’t mind ruining. Most types of spray-on snow are designed to wash out of clothing, but there’s no guarantee that they will.

steps.headline: Hold the can at least 6–12 inches (15–30 cm) away from the item while spraying.
steps.description: Keeping the can slightly further away from the piece will result in a wider spray arc and therefore help you achieve a lighter, more even coat. If you hold it too close, or spray too long, the fluid will be more likely to form unsightly, wet-looking blobs. Position your item at a height that will allow you to spray it from above comfortably. Don’t forget to shake the can thoroughly before you start spraying!

steps.headline: Start at the top of the item and work your way down.
steps.description: Begin with the upper part of the piece, moving the can back and forth slowly to hit it from many different angles. Then, lower the can a few inches and do the same for the next section. Continue in this way until you’ve touched up each section of the piece you want to enhance. It’s not recommended that you use spray-on products to flock full-sized Christmas trees, as it would simply be too time-consuming. They’re generally better suited for small-to-medium-sized decorations.Tip: When customizing a tree, wreath, or garland, focus the spray around the tops of the branches or needles to more accurately simulate the way that snow accumulates.

steps.headline: Allow the spray to dry for 8-12 hours before handling your item.
steps.description: Most flocking sprays dry to the touch in a matter of hours. To avoid ruining the appearance of the finish, however, it’s best to let the piece sit undisturbed overnight. When you come back to it, it will be just like waking up to a snowy Christmas morning! Resist the urge to touch the fresh snow for a minimum of 1-2 hours after applying it. You’ll also want to hold off on moving or relocating your item for the same amount of time. If you decide to touch up any part of the piece, wait for the initial coat to dry for at least 15 minutes before you begin your second round of spraying.
